{include "default_salutation"} –

We are seeing rising numbers of COVID-19 cases, and here in Arkansas, people incarcerated in state prisons continue to face imminent risk of illness or death due to the state's inadequate response to this public health crisis.

Sadly, Arkansas is currently number two in the country for prison coronavirus cases and deaths per capita, and incarcerated people continue to report inadequate medical care and a lack of adequate cleaning supplies and PPE. Our elected officials are consistently failing to protect against COVID-19 spread and illness.

Something must be done.

On Wednesday, December 2, we will be joining the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc. (LDF), the law firm Squire Patton Boggs, DecARcerate, and Disability Rights Arkansas for an update on our litigation challenging the state's failure to contain outbreaks in the state's correctional facilities, and the need to continue sounding the alarm about the risks incarcerated people – and the surrounding communities – face. RSVP now for this virtual town hall event.

The failure to adhere to CDC guidelines disproportionately harms Black Arkansans, who are both overrepresented in the state prison system and are infected with and die from COVID-19 at double their percentage of the state population. These gross missteps by our officials to protect incarcerated people and surrounding communities should not be overlooked.

Join our virtual town hall on Wednesday, December 2 and learn how you can help us sound the alarm. RSVP now.
